body:
We are planning to start flume agents dynamically and it comes handy to be able to override parameters of a base configuration file without actually touching and modifying it, for example change the bind port.  

Example:  

agent.sources.avro-collection-source.bind = localhost
agent.sources.avro-collection-source.port = 50000
agent.sinks.hdfs-sink.hdfs.path = hdfs://localhost:9000/flume
agent.channels.memoryChannel.capacity = 20000

flume-ng agent -n agent -f flume.conf 
-o avro-collection-source.bind=0.0.0.0 
-o avro-collection-source.port=30000
-o hdfs-sink.hdfs.path=hdfs://localhost:9000/data
-o memoryChannel.capacity=30000

From a quick look the issue is that when the channel is stopped, it gets closed and queueRemaining is set to null. So when it is restarted the variable is not initialized again.

@gherreros, thanks for feed back.  when I review the code of SpillableMemoryChannel for the test part , it also failed for the same reason while re-configuring the SpillableMemoryChannel just as you pointed out for the step:  channel.stop()  then channel.start() it would throw the exception for open is not true while checking.  what's the more, when such begins, it will nonstop unless I restart so I wonder how could I resolve such problem for I don't want to restart the whole flume. and please help me and leave me some advice for how to use SpillableMemoryChannel well.
I will create a patch and attach it to a JIRA

I have also sent a couple of message to flume-dev list and tried sending emails to flume a couple of moderators/contributors email addressed documented on the flume's team page, with no avail.
any advise????

Isn't like on linux you should put make an independent directory in plugins.d like this:

$FLUME_HOME/plugins.d/pluginName/lib/yourPlugin
$FLUME_HOME/plugins.d/pluginName/libext/yourPluginDep

Hi Ara. Thanks for contributing this!

I haven't taken a look at the code quite yet, but one quick thought: would it be best to have this code hosted in the Flume project or in the Kudu project? I can think of a couple pros/cons:

Pros for contributing as part of the Flume repo:
- I think this is the "standard" -- eg the flume repo already has sinks for many other systems like elastic search, hbase, kafka, etc. So, seems like it would make sense to put Kudu in there as well.
- Flume users will have more of a "batteries included" experience -- no need to muck with classpaths or move jars into place, etc, to write to Kudu.

Pros for hosting as part of the Kudu repo:
- It's likely that, since Flume is a relatively stable/mature project, its APIs aren't going to break. Kudu is still in beta with new APIs and capabilities being added reasonably rapidly. Versioning the flume sink inside the Kudu repo will make it easier to (a) ensure that Kudu changes don't break the flume sink, and (b) quickly evolve the Flume sink to take advantage of those new features.
- Currently, the Kudu project doesn't export any "minicluster" JAR for use by external projects. So, it will be impossible to do any integration testing of the Kudu sink if it's part of the Flume project. On the other hand, if we include it in the Kudu repo, we already have build/test infrastructure that runs a local minicluster and we could easily write some simple integration tests.

Any thoughts on this? Would also like to solicit thoughts from the rest of the Flume community as well. Thanks.

Hi Todd.

Ill contact the Kudu guys and see what their preference is. Perhaps for now Kudu repos would be a better place for hosting these? Because Kudu is at v0.6 and not yet stable in many way.

Ara.

> Pros for hosting as part of the Kudu repo:

Versioning the flume sink inside the Kudu repo will make it easier to (a) ensure that Kudu changes don't break the flume sink, and (b) quickly evolve the Flume sink to take advantage of those new features.
> Currently, the Kudu project doesn't export any "minicluster" JAR for use by external projects. So, it will be impossible to do any integration testing of the Kudu sink if it's part of the Flume project. On the other hand, if we include it in the Kudu repo, we already have build/test infrastructure that runs a local minicluster and we could easily write some simple integration tests.
> Any thoughts on this? Would also like to solicit thoughts from the rest of the Flume community as well. Thanks.

Hey Ara. I am one of the Kudu guys :) Let's see what the Flume guys think, though.

Oh ok :)

Ara.

> On Feb 12, 2016, at 1:05 PM, Todd Lipcon notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Hey Ara. I am one of the Kudu guys :) Let's see what the Flume guys think, though.
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub https://github.com/apache/flume/pull/36#issuecomment-183488015.

Considering the fact that Kudu is a new component that is still evolving, changing quite rapidly and is on much faster release schedule then flume, I would not mind having the Kudu sink part of kudu repository for the time being.

(I'm a Flume PMC member, but I'm representing my own opinion here)

Until Kudu's APIs are stable and mature, I agree that having it in the Kudu project is probably a good idea. I would be really glad to have it in Flume once Kudu APIs are final and stable (and if testing would be easy).
Could you please submit this as patch against the trunk branch on the jira? We don't do PRs yet on Flume

Hi @arae I'm a committer on both projects and I agree with @toddlipcon, @jarcec and @harishreedharan that this would be good to have as part of Kudu, at least for now. That would also allow us to test it using the MiniCluster. Right now Kudu doesn't ship MiniCluster binaries in a way that is downloadable via Maven (although I believ the java classes for the MiniCluster are be available via Maven). Would you mind squashing your PR into one commit and submitting a Gerrit CR to Kudu? Instructions are here: http://getkudu.io/docs/contributing.html

Sure.

Ara.

At first glance it seems like your change is conflicting with this one:
FLUME-2918. Speed up TaildirSource on directories with many files
https://github.com/apache/flume/commit/7d1e683fbd7d261fff9fcf17ad78fd8469c64905

@satiatcloudera Thanks for your remind. I will check FLUME-2918. In addition to the function of recursive directory access, multiline is supported and also fix the bug if a lines length exceeds 8192 bytes. In order to get some common messages such as filepath from sinkI add filepath,hostname,ip in the header of flume event.

@satiatcloudera I review the FLUME-2918. It does not support recursive directory.  I have two tests as follows:

1.
filegroups.ab=/var/folders/g9/gbqgyz4n2_17b39prgl002xm0000gn/._/1467730207992-0/[ab].log filepath=/var/folders/g9/gbqgyz4n2_17b39prgl002xm0000gn/T/1467730207992-0/a.log
In TaildirMatcher.TaildirMatcher() {... this.parentDir = f.getParentFile(); ...} ,  parentDir value is  /var/folders/g9/gbqgyz4n2_17b39prgl002xm0000gn/._/1467730207992-0. So it returns exception :
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Directory does not exist: /var/folders/g9/gbqgyz4n2_17b39prgl002xm0000gn/.*/1467730207992-0
    at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkState(Preconditions.java:145)

2.
filegroups.ab=/var/folders/g9/gbqgyz4n2_17b39prgl002xm0000gn/T/1467730207992-0/.*[ab].log filepath=/var/folders/g9/gbqgyz4n2_17b39prgl002xm0000gn/T/1467730207992-0/01/a.log
    I found a.log can't be tracked by the taildirsource

Hi @tinawenqiao,

Sorry for the confusion, on the source level I suspected conflicts, not on the functionality level. Would you mind moving this discussion to the dev list of flume (dev@flume.apache.org)? So that community can also help you?

Your three changes sounds like three different improvements. 
1) Sounds like a good improvement for TailDirSource (please check Spooling Directory Source how similar is supported using deserializer: https://flume.apache.org/FlumeUserGuide.html#spooling-directory-source) Your logic can be a part of a new deserializer.
2) This is something looks very specific to your use case. I believe it could be a little bit more generalised and or driven by configuration parameter(s).
3) Sounds like a good improvement for TailDirSource but would be good to avoid inventing a new pattern syntax (please check out the latest development on SpoolingDirSource as it is now capable of checking a directory subtree recursively)

Cheers,
Attila

I had made a simple implementation, deal directly with gz data source:
https://github.com/styg/bumblebee-ETL/tree/master/src/main/java/com/gsta/bigdata/etl/flume

As requested on [JIRA FLUME-2911](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLUME-2911), I documented what happens when ignorePattern and includePattern are combined and both match for a given file in the spooling directory.

Added two tests to stress what happens in case both the options are declared and they go in conflict each other, according to [original JIRA request](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLUME-2911).

+1. Please go ahead and commit.

I'm about to commit this

We actually recommend the following setup: `export MAVEN_OPTS="-Xms512m -Xmx1024m -XX:PermSize=256m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m"`. Have you experienced any issues with this configuration?

Do you think we should enable the tests after we have fixed our flaky tests?

@liorze : thank you for the comment!

I actually copied it from my local environment. That's what I have been using.
(Btw, it looks like to me we aren't exactly consistent with these options. See DEVNOTES vs. README.md)

Regarding the tests: yes, that's what I think.
I see two options:
We either fix all the flakiness and make sure it all fits into reasonable time limits.
Or, we create different test suites, one for smoke testing and another one which contains all the tests we have. (Because some of them aren't exactly "unit" tests, afaik.)

I'll update the DEVNOTES as part of FLUME-2945, thanks.

Re/ tests, I think we have a few more tests to fix, it looks doable. Let's give it a try and go with plan b if it takes to much time to fix.

@liorze : thank you for offering to fix the DEVNOTES. (Although, I'm not sure how this is related to switching to Java 8)

Do you have any other review comments for this change?

It's related because the `MaxPermSize` option is deprecated in Java 8.

No, LGTM.

I think, if we have MAVEN_OPTS = "..." mvn, then we need to have MAVEN_SKIP_RC = 1.

If we are going to use multiple mvn ... commands, then I think it's easier to set it up in one place. (before_install)

The caching is to speed up the builds. ( https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/caching/#Arbitrary-directories )
I can remove it, that's fine.

> The caching is to speed up the builds.

Thanks for helping me understand. Maybe add a comment about this for people new to Travis?

> I think, if we have MAVEN_OPTS = "..." mvn, then we need to have MAVEN_SKIP_RC = 1.

Why? I don't understand the reason

> If we are going to use multiple mvn ... commands, then I think it's easier to set it up in one place. 

We aren't doing that yet, right? Would we ever do that?

Personally I like to avoid putting stuff in default locations for build scripts in order to avoid unintended side effects either in other concurrent builds or in future builds. I just don't like to "pollute" the environment. However, I'm guessing Travis uses a Docker image or something like that and wipes out the home dir before each build so you can leave cruft in $HOME and it will never affect future builds. Is that right?
